thread.title: Pimco Optimistic For European Recovery

title: Pimco Optimistic For European Recovery
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Sep 24, 2015, 14:27 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 3 mins Pimco Optimistic For European Recovery The Wall Street Journal – 33 minutes ago Print It has been a messy quarter for markets with many regions suffering their worst stock market declines in four years as fears of a slowdown in China ballooned. 
But at least for Europe’s growth story it might not really matter, portfolio managers at Pacific Investment Management Company LLC say in their latest report. 
“Despite the market volatility in Asia and some turbulence in Europe around the difficult situation in Greece, our expectations are for the eurozone to experience above-trend real growth of 1.75%” over the next twelve months, Pimco managing director and portfolio manager Mike Amey writes. 
“Undoubtedly, there will be some challenges for the export sector, in particular for the German economy, as exports to Asia come under pressure; however, our assessment is that this recovery is becoming an increasingly domestic affair,” he adds. 
The team at Pimco is also confident that the European Central Bank’s program of bond purchases will continue to bolster the European economy and support appetite for borrowing and lending. 
“Companies and households are taking out more loans and mortgages, so were are seeing credit beginning to grow again,” writes managing director and portfolio manager Andrew Bosomworth, adding that “business and consumer confidence has risen and economic growth has stabilized.” 
Beyond the euro area, the team is also optimistic that the U.K. can keep pace with Europe and continue to flourish in the face of headwinds from elsewhere. 
“The worry for some time has been the resilience of the recovery in the face of poor productivity growth, lower public spending and a stronger sterling,” Mr. Amey says. 
“However, with mounting evidence of rising productivity ad real wage growth, the U.K. recovery now looks well supported. Our expectation Is for real growth to continue at an above-trend pace of 2.5% over the next 12 months.” 
He adds that the Bank of England is most likely to start raising interest rates in May 2016. More from The Wall Street Journal
